thread.title_full: Blackhawks score two power-play goals to down Panthers 3-2 Thursday - Sun Sentinel

author: Harvey Fialkov
title: Blackhawks score two power-play goals to down Panthers 3-2 Thursday
text:
Panthers general manager Dale Tallon certainly played a major role in rebuilding the Chicago Blackhawks into three-time Stanley Cup champions over the last six years when he was making personnel decisions for them.
Tallon's drafting skills and eight penalties came back to bite the Panthers Thursday evening with two of his draft picks, Brent Seabrook and Patrick Kane, scoring power-play goals to propel the defending champs to a 3-2 victory in the sold-out United Center.
It was the Panthers (3-3-1) third straight loss and eighth in a row to the Blackhawks (4-3). They haven't won in Chicago since Dec. 16, 2007 and now head to Dallas for a rematch with the surging Stars, who have won five in a row.
They may be without top-line center Aleksander Barkov, who sustained an injury to his right hand in the second period when blocking a shot. Barkov’s hand was wrapped after the game and he will be further evaluated on Friday. Barkov has three goals with six points in his first seven games.
“It’s a big loss. He’s our best player,’’ said Jaromir Jagr, Barkov’s linemate. “He’s going to be tough to replace. Nobody knows for how long he’s going to be out. It’s going to be even tougher. We got to do it no matter what.’’
All the action from the United Center.
For a while Tallon certainly didn't get much respect from the referees in his hometown. The penalty calls were lopsided for most of the game as at one juncture the Blackhawks had six power plays (8 total) to the Panthers' one.
“Sometimes it’s tough calls,’’ said Jagr, who had two of Florida’s penalties, but scored a power-play goal of his own. “We give them too much time on power play. Same thing in Pittsburgh, same thing here. Usually it’s like that when you play the champions they deserve the respect, so they got it.’’
Tied at 1-1 after the first period, the Panthers gave the Blackhawks two consecutive power plays in the first 3:33. That was one too many as after defenseman Steve Kampfer went off with a hook, Seabrook's dipping slapper from just inside the blue line deflected off the stick of former Blackhawks center Dave Bolland and Roberto Luongo's glove for a 2-1 lead at 3:51.
The Panthers nearly replied on their next rush, however, Corey Crawford made a sprawling glove save to stone Jagr. Still, despite being outshot 21-9 after two, the Panthers only trailed 2-1 heading into the third.
The Panthers were shorthanded for 7:36 of the middle frame and it carried over for 42 seconds of the third period. Kane, the overall No. 1 draft pick by Tallon in 2007, needed just 17 seconds to lift a backhander over Luongo for his fifth goal of the season and a 3-1 lead.
“That’s too good of a team to be reaching on. We have to play them harder and a little more cleaner,’’ said center Nick Bjugstad. “Obviously, that power play is scary. That definitely slowed the momentum for us. … It’s not fun killing penalties against these guys. We knew that.’’
Perhaps the referees felt they had been unfair as they handed out a four-minute penalty to Marcus Kruger and then just six seconds later got Niklas Hjalmarsson for a delay of game. With 10 ticks left on the 5-on-3 advantage, Jagr tapped in a rebound of Vincent Trocheck's shot to make it a one-goal deficit with 12:36 left.
It was Jagr's team-leading fifth goal, his 727th career goal and his 206th power-play goal to move him past Joe Sakic into 13th place all time. Hihs 588th power-play point tied him with Teemu Selanne for third place in the history books.
After two straight losses Panthers coach Gerard Gallant felt it was time to do some tinkering with his lineup.
So Gallant flopped his right wings, Trocheck and Reilly Smith, on the second and third lines to bolster the offense, and replaced rookie defenseman Alex Petrovic after a subpar game in this week's 3-2 loss to the Penguins with Kampfer.
Blackhawks forward Artem Anisimov swooped around a flat-footed Kampfer and then Dmitry Kulikov before flicking it in at 4:02 of the first period. Just 34 seconds later, Trocheck who was promoted to the second line with Nick Bjugstad and Brandon Pirri, took turns poking at a loose puck in the crease before jabbing it in.
Trocheck notched his first point and goal since notching a goal and three assists in the season opener.
“I’m trying to drive the net. That’s something I got away from since the start of the season,’’ said Trocheck, who also played on the top line when Barkov went out. “I just got to go hard and get to the net for a dirty goal, that’s why I hit it 10, 15 times until it went in.’’
Gallant said Kampfer played fine despite a slow start.
"Last year Kampfer played real well and hadn't had a chance to play this year,'' Gallant said earlier. "There was some things I didn't like but [Petrovic] has played good overall for six games.''
Loungo's sterling glove save on a point-blank shot from Jonathan Toews kept the Panthers tied at 1-1 after the first period despite getting outshot 12-4.
The final nail came when the Jagr got another penalty with 2:21 remaining to basically take away the strategy to pull the goalie. They got one more whistle with three seconds left to give the Blackhawks their eighth power play (16 minutes) to Florida’s four. Chicago outshot the Panthers 27-18.
“Too much. We had five in the second period and killed any momentum we had,’’ Gallant said of the penalties. “Chicago’s a good team and they pretty well dominated the game most of the night.’’ …
 "I'm proud in what we did as a staff in Chicago to make something special here," Tallon said before the game. "We're kind of mirroring Chicago a little bit; it's getting there. We've got 10 draft picks on the team right now and the goal is to get 15. … The future looks really good."
